thread.title: Diane Abbott says Jeremy Corbyn should not quit even if Labour were to lose both crunch by-elections
thread.title_full: Diane Abbott says Jeremy Corbyn should not quit even if Labour were to lose both crunch by-elections - Mirror Online

author: mirror.co.uk
title: Diane Abbott says Jeremy Corbyn should not quit even if Labour were to lose both crunch by-elections

persons.name: nicholas soames sadiq khan jamie reed jeremy corbyn

organizations.name: politics labour party conservative party michael foot tristram hunt

text:
Diane Abbott says Jeremy Corbyn should not quit even if Labour were to lose both crunch by-elections The Shadow Home Secretary warned polls in Copeland and Stoke-on-Trent Central would be "quite tight" and urged backers to come out and vote Share Comments By Dan Bloom 12:58, 19 FEB 2017 Updated 13:11, 19 FEB 2017 News Diane Abbott defended her ally Jeremy Corbyn and said he should stay in post (Photo: Sky News) politics Jeremy Corbyn should stay in his job even if Labour loses both of its crunch by-elections this week, Diane Abbott has said.
Labour are the bookies' favourites to beat UKIP in Stoke-on-Trent Central, where the left-wing party has a 5,000 majority, this Thursday.
But despite a disastrous visit by Theresa May, the Tories are currently leading bets on overturning Labour's 2,500 majority in Copeland, Cumbria.
Today Ms Abbott said both polls would be "quite tight" - and the worst case scenario should not spell the end for her ally Mr Corbyn.
Read More Diane Abbott reveals vile racist abuse that has led to fears for her walking the streets alone She told Sky News' Sophy Ridge on Sunday: "These are difficult by-elections. They are going to be quite tight.
Jeremy Corbyn and candidate Gareth Snell meet 11-month-old Margot Dallimie in Stoke (Photo: Getty) "And if we lose one, if we lose both, I think the party will go forward", his ally said (Photo: Getty) "We are hopeful of winning both of them but it's really important that every Labour supporter comes out to vote.
"And if we lose one, if we lose both, I think the party will go forward. It has to go forward."
Asked if a loss would raise questions over Mr Corbyn's leadership, she said: "No. No. There are people who've been opposed to Jeremy from the very beginning. I'm not one of them, and I think we have to go forward."
She blamed a "sustained campaign" by the media and some Labour MPs for poor polling, and said: "I'm confident Jeremy will lead us into 2020."
The polls were prompted by the quitting of two Labour MPs to go to new jobs.
Diane Abbott said the party would still be in the right position regardless of the result (Photo: Getty) Jeremy Corbyn campaigning in Stoke-on-Trent yesterday ahead of the poll (Photo: Getty) Shadow Justice Secretary Richard Burgon told BBC Radio 5 Live: "I think those two by-elections are not going to be easy by-elections. Contrary to some reports Copeland is not a so-called safe Labour seat."
Asked if he’d written it off he said: "I haven’t written it off. I believe Labour can win both of these by-elections, but I think it will be tough and I believe it will probably be close. I believe every vote will count."
On Copeland, he said: “It’s been held by and large mostly by small majorities and then there are other challenges in Stoke."
MPs with more centrist views than Mr Corbyn, including Peter Kyle and Liz Kendall, today insisted Labour would win the by-elections.
And London mayor Sadiq Khan batted aside questions of Jeremy Corbyn's leadership, telling ITV's Peston on Sunday: "He’s won two leadership elections in the space of two years. I think that issue’s been settled."
Richard Burgon said: "Contrary to reports Copeland is not a so-called safe seat" Sadiq Khan said: "He’s won two leadership elections in two years. That issue’s settled" (Photo: Rex) However, Mr Khan added it was Labour's job to win elections, not be a "protest party".
He said: "We serve our party and country best when we’re in positions of power and influence."
Tory MP Nicholas Soames said Labour was now the weakest it has been for 33 years - claiming Jeremy Corbyn did not have the "calibre" of Michael Foot.
He told ITV's Peston on Sunday: "I regret it and I think it’s telling that two good Labour MPs, Tristram Hunt and Jamie Reed, both left."
In a speech last week, Nigel Farage piled pressure on Ukip leader and candidate Paul Nuttall to win in Stoke, warning he'd had a “tough week”.
He added: “I don't think anybody for one moment can underplay just how important, just how fundamental that by-election is for the futures of both the Labour party and indeed of UKIP.”
